topic_name: Human Body - Nervous System and Sense Organs

canonical_explanation.text: The nervous system controls and coordinates all body activities. It consists of the brain (control centre), spinal cord (connects brain to body), and nerves (carry messages). The brain controls thinking, memory, and body functions. We have five sense organs: eyes (sight), ears (hearing), nose (smell), tongue (taste), and skin (touch). Each sense organ has specialized receptors. The eye has parts like cornea, pupil, lens, and retina. The ear has outer ear, ear canal, and eardrum. Reflexes are quick automatic responses like blinking. We must protect and care for our sense organs.
rules: Brain: control centre of the body
Spinal cord: connects brain to rest of body
Nerves: carry messages to and from brain
Five sense organs: eyes, ears, nose, tongue, skin

questions.question_text: Which organ is called the control centre of the body?
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is the control centre of the body because it receives and processes information from all parts of the body, and then sends instructions to the body to make it work properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The heart, lungs, and stomach are all important organs, but they do not control all the activities of the body. The brain is the control centre because it receives information from the senses, stores memories, and sends instructions to the rest of the body to make it work.

questions.question_text: How many sense organs do we have?
questions.explanation_correct: We have five sense organs - eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and skin. So the correct answer is that we have five sense organs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because we have five sense organs, not three, four, or six. The five sense organs are our eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and skin. Each of these organs has specialized receptors that allow us to see, hear, smell, taste, and feel the world around us.

questions.question_text: Which sense organ helps us to see?
questions.explanation_correct: The eyes are the sense organ that helps us see. The eyes have special parts like the cornea, pupil, lens, and retina that work together to allow us to see the world around us.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eyes are the sense organ that helps us see, not the ears, nose, or tongue. The eyes have special parts like the cornea, pupil, lens, and retina that work together to allow us to see. The ears, nose, and tongue are the sense organs for hearing, smell, and taste, respectively.

questions.question_text: Which sense organ is responsible for hearing?
questions.explanation_correct: The ears are the sense organs responsible for hearing. They have specialized parts like the outer ear, ear canal, and eardrum that work together to detect and process sound waves, allowing us to hear different sounds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eyes are not responsible for hearing. The ears contain parts like the outer ear, ear canal, and eardrum that work together to detect and process sound waves, allowing us to hear different sounds. The skin, nose, and tongue are responsible for the other senses of touch, smell, and taste, respectively.

questions.question_text: What connects the brain to the rest of the body?
questions.explanation_correct: The spinal cord connects the brain to the rest of the body. It acts like a highway, carrying messages and signals between the brain and the different parts of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The muscles, bones, and blood vessels are not the connectors between the brain and the body. The correct answer is the spinal cord, which is a long, thick bundle of nerves that extends from the brain down the back. The spinal cord acts as the main communication pathway, allowing the brain to control and coordinate the functions of the entire body.

questions.question_text: Nerves carry _____ to and from the brain.
questions.explanation_correct: Nerves carry messages to and from the brain. The nervous system uses nerves to send and receive information, so the correct answer is B) Messages.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nerves do not carry blood, food, or water to and from the brain. The nervous system is responsible for sending and receiving messages, not transporting these other things. The correct answer is B) Messages, which the nerves use to communicate with the brain and body.

questions.question_text: Which sense organ helps us to smell?
questions.explanation_correct: The nose is the sense organ that helps us to smell. It has special receptors that can detect different smells and send messages to the brain to identify them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tongue is the sense organ that helps us taste different flavors, not smell. The skin helps us feel touch and temperature, not smell. The eyes help us see, not smell. The correct answer is the nose, which has special cells that can detect different smells and send this information to the brain.

questions.question_text: The sense of taste is associated with which organ?
questions.explanation_correct: The sense of taste is associated with the tongue. The tongue has specialized taste receptors that detect different tastes like sweet, sour, salty, and bitter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sense of taste is not associated with the nose, skin, or ears. The nose is responsible for the sense of smell, the skin for the sense of touch, and the ears for the sense of hearing. The tongue is the specialized organ that allows us to taste different flavors.

questions.question_text: Which organ helps us feel hot, cold, and pain?
questions.explanation_correct: The skin is the organ that helps us feel hot, cold, and pain. It has special receptors that detect these sensations and send messages to the brain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eyes, ears, and nose are sense organs that help us see, hear, and smell, respectively. However, the skin is the organ that allows us to feel sensations like hot, cold, and pain. The skin has special cells called receptors that detect these physical changes and send messages to the brain.

questions.question_text: Which part of the nervous system controls thinking and memory?
questions.explanation_correct: The brain controls all our thinking, memory, and body functions. It is the command centre of the nervous system, so the correct answer is C) Brain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The spinal cord (A) connects the brain to the rest of the body and helps transmit messages, but it doesn't directly control thinking and memory. The nerves (B) carry messages to and from the brain, but they don't control these functions either. Muscles (D) are responsible for movement, not thinking and memory.

questions.question_text: When you touch a hot pan and quickly pull your hand away, this is an example of:
questions.explanation_correct: When you touch a hot pan, your body instantly pulls your hand away without you having to think about it. This is called a reflex action, which is a quick automatic response to a stimulus. Reflexes happen very quickly to protect your body from harm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pulling your hand away from a hot pan is not an example of thinking, a slow response, or a voluntary action. Thinking requires you to consciously consider your actions, a slow response would take longer, and a voluntary action is something you choose to do. In this case, your body instantly pulls your hand away as a reflex to protect you from the hot pan.

questions.question_text: Why do we close our eyes when bright light shines suddenly?

options.text: It is a reflex to protect our eyes

questions.explanation_correct: We close our eyes when bright light shines suddenly because it is a reflex to protect our eyes. Our body has a natural reaction to sudden bright light, which makes us blink to avoid hurting our eyes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We do not close our eyes to see better. Closing the eyes when there is bright light is not because we are scared or tired, but it is an automatic reflex that helps protect our eyes from the strong light. Our body is designed to react quickly in this way to prevent damage to the sensitive parts of our eyes.

questions.question_text: Why should we not listen to very loud music through headphones?
questions.explanation_correct: Listening to very loud music through headphones can damage our ears. The loud sound can hurt the delicate parts inside our ears and cause hearing loss over time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Listening to loud music through headphones is not good because it can damage the sensitive parts inside our ears. When the sound is too loud, it can hurt the eardrum and other small parts that help us hear. This can lead to hearing problems or even deafness if we keep listening to very loud music for a long time.

questions.question_text: A chef uses which sense organ mainly to check if the food tastes good?
questions.explanation_correct: The tongue is the main sense organ that the chef uses to check if the food tastes good. The tongue has taste receptors that can detect the different tastes in the food, such as sweet, sour, salty, and bitter.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eyes, ears, and skin are not the main sense organs used by the chef to check the taste of the food. The tongue has special taste receptors that can identify the different flavors in the food, which is why the chef uses the tongue to taste and evaluate the food.

questions.question_text: When you smell something burning in the kitchen, which sense organ alerts you?
questions.explanation_correct: When you smell something burning in the kitchen, your nose is the sense organ that alerts you. The nose contains specialized receptors that can detect different smells, including the smell of something burning. This allows your brain to recognize the smell and warn you about the potential fire hazard.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tongue is used for the sense of taste, not smell. The ears are used for the sense of hearing, and the eyes are used for the sense of sight. The nose is the sense organ that detects different smells, including the smell of something burning in the kitchen.

questions.question_text: If nerves are damaged in a person's leg, what might happen?

options.text: They may not feel sensations in that leg

questions.explanation_correct: If the nerves in a person's leg are damaged, they may not be able to feel sensations like touch, pain, or temperature in that leg. This is because the nerves carry messages from the leg to the brain, and when they are damaged, the brain cannot receive these messages properly.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because they do not relate to the nerves in the leg. Damaged nerves in the leg would not affect a person's sight, hearing, or sense of smell. The nervous system is responsible for sending messages to and from the brain, and if the nerves in the leg are damaged, it would affect the sense of touch and feeling in that leg, but not the other senses.

questions.question_text: Which part of the eye controls the amount of light entering?
questions.explanation_correct: The pupil is the opening in the center of the eye that controls the amount of light entering the eye. The pupil can get bigger or smaller to let in more or less light, helping us see clearly in different lighting conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The lens focuses light, but it doesn't control the amount of light entering the eye. The cornea is the clear front part of the eye, but it also doesn't control light. The retina is at the back of the eye and receives the light, but it doesn't control the amount of light entering.

questions.question_text: Why do we need a nervous system?

options.text: To coordinate and control body activities

questions.explanation_correct: We need the nervous system to coordinate and control all the activities of our body. The nervous system is like the 'control centre' that tells different parts of the body what to do and when to do it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The nervous system is not for digesting food, pumping blood, or breathing air. These are other important body functions that are controlled by different systems. The nervous system is responsible for coordinating and controlling all the activities of our body, like moving, thinking, and responding to our surroundings.

questions.question_text: The eardrum vibrates when sound waves enter the ear. This vibration is essential for:
questions.explanation_correct: The eardrum vibrates when sound waves enter the ear. This vibration is essential for hearing because it helps transmit the sound signals to the brain, allowing us to hear and understand the sounds around us.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eardrum vibrates when sound waves enter the ear, but this vibration is not essential for seeing, smelling, or tasting. The eardrum's vibration is specifically needed for the sense of hearing, as it helps convert the sound waves into electrical signals that the brain can interpret as sounds.

questions.question_text: The spinal cord is protected by the:
questions.explanation_correct: The spinal cord is protected by the backbone, also called the vertebral column. The vertebral column is made up of small bones called vertebrae that surround and protect the spinal cord.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The spinal cord is not protected by the skull, ribs, or muscles. The skull protects the brain, the ribs protect the organs in the chest, and the muscles help move the body. The spinal cord is protected by the backbone or vertebral column, which is a series of small bones that surround and shield the spinal cord.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a function of the brain?
questions.explanation_correct: The brain does not pump blood, as that is the function of the heart. The brain controls important body functions like thinking, memory, and movement, but it does not directly pump blood through the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is the control center of the body and it has many important functions. It controls our thinking, helps us remember things, and coordinates the movements of our body. However, the brain does not pump blood. That job is done by the heart, which is a different organ in our body.

questions.question_text: Images are formed on which part of the eye?
questions.explanation_correct: The images we see are formed on the retina at the back of the eye. The retina has special light-sensitive cells that convert the light into electrical signals, which are then sent to the brain for interpretation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The images we see are not formed on the cornea, pupil, or lens. The cornea is the clear front part of the eye that helps focus light. The pupil is the opening that lets light into the eye. The lens is behind the pupil and also helps focus light. The images are actually formed on the retina, which is the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye.

questions.question_text: Reading in dim light can cause:
questions.explanation_correct: Reading in dim light can cause eye strain because the eyes have to work harder to see clearly in low light conditions. This can lead to tired, strained eyes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reading in dim light does not cause problems with the ears, skin, or taste. The eyes are the only sense organ affected, as they have to work harder to see clearly in low light, leading to eye strain and fatigue.

questions.question_text: A blind person uses which sense organ to read Braille?
questions.explanation_correct: A blind person uses their sense of touch, specifically their fingertips, to read Braille. Braille is a system of raised dots that represent letters and numbers, and a blind person can feel these dots with their fingertips to understand the text.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eyes are used for sight, not for reading Braille. Similarly, the ears are used for hearing, and the nose is used for smell. Braille is read using the sense of touch, with the fingertips being the most sensitive part of the skin to feel the raised dots that make up the Braille characters.

questions.question_text: When you feel the texture of a cloth, which sense are you using?
questions.explanation_correct: When you feel the texture of a cloth, you are using your sense of touch. The receptors in your skin can detect the different textures and shapes of the cloth, allowing you to feel its softness, roughness, or other qualities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sight, smell, and taste are not used to feel the texture of a cloth. Sight is used to see the cloth, smell is used to detect any scents from the cloth, and taste is used to detect the flavor of something you put in your mouth. The sense of touch, using the receptors in your skin, is the one that allows you to feel the texture of the cloth.

questions.question_text: The brain is protected by the:
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is protected by the skull. The skull is a hard, bony structure that covers and surrounds the brain to protect it from injury.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is not protected by the ribs, backbone, or skin. The ribs protect the chest and lungs, the backbone protects the spinal cord, and the skin is the outer layer of the body. The brain is the control center of the body and needs a strong, protective structure to keep it safe, which is the skull.

questions.question_text: Why should we not put sharp objects in our ears?
questions.explanation_correct: We should not put sharp objects in our ears because they can damage the eardrum. The eardrum is a thin, sensitive membrane inside the ear that can easily get hurt by sharp things.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are not the correct reasons why we should not put sharp objects in our ears. They are expensive and can make noise, but those are not the main reasons. Putting sharp objects in the ear is dangerous because they can easily damage the delicate eardrum, which is an important part of our hearing system.

questions.question_text: The transparent front part of the eye that lets light enter is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is C) Cornea. The cornea is the transparent front part of the eye that lets light enter and focus on the lens and retina at the back of the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is C) Cornea. The cornea is not the pupil (the black opening in the middle of the eye), the lens (the clear, curved structure behind the pupil), or the retina (the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye). The cornea is the clear, curved front part of the eye that focuses the light entering the eye.

questions.question_text: Which two sense organs work together when we eat food?
questions.explanation_correct: The tongue and nose work together when we eat food. The tongue helps us taste the food, while the nose helps us smell the food. This allows us to fully experience the flavor and aroma of the food we eat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The eyes and ears do not help us taste or smell food. The skin and eyes also do not work together when we eat. The correct answer is the tongue and nose, because they are the sense organs that allow us to experience the taste and smell of the food we put in our mouths.

questions.question_text: When you have a cold and your nose is blocked, food may taste different because:
questions.explanation_correct: When your nose is blocked, you can't smell the food as well. Smell helps a lot in how we taste food. So if you can't smell the food properly, it won't taste the same.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Smell helps in tasting food. Your tongue is still working properly when you have a cold, so A) is not correct. Your eyes are also not affected, so C) is not right. And your ears being blocked does not change how food tastes, so D) is also incorrect.

questions.question_text: The brain is the control centre of our body.
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is the control centre of our body. It controls all the activities of the body and helps us think, remember, and function properly. The brain is the most important part of the nervous system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is not the only control centre of our body. The nervous system, which includes the brain, spinal cord, and nerves, works together to control and coordinate all the activities of the body. While the brain is the main control centre, the spinal cord and nerves also play an important role in the functioning of the body.

questions.question_text: We have four sense organs.
questions.explanation_correct: The statement is false. We have five main sense organs - eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and skin. The five senses are sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is incorrect. We have five sense organs, not four. The five sense organs are the eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and skin. Each of these sense organs has specialized receptors that allow us to see, hear, smell, taste, and feel touch.

questions.question_text: The tongue is the organ of taste.
questions.explanation_correct: The tongue is the organ of taste. The tongue has taste buds that can detect different taste sensations like sweet, sour, salty, and bitter. This allows us to taste and enjoy the food we eat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement 'The tongue is the organ of taste' is true. The tongue has specialized taste receptors called taste buds that can detect different tastes. This allows us to experience and recognize the flavors of the food we consume.

questions.question_text: Nerves carry messages from the brain to different parts of the body.
questions.explanation_correct: Nerves do carry messages from the brain to different parts of the body. The brain is the control centre of the nervous system, and it sends messages through the nerves to make our body parts work.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think that nerves only carry messages from the body to the brain, but that's not true. Nerves have two-way communication - they carry messages both from the brain to the body parts, and from the body parts back to the brain. This allows the brain to control and coordinate all the activities of the body.

questions.question_text: Reflex actions are slow and require thinking.
questions.explanation_correct: Reflex actions are quick, automatic responses to a stimulus. They happen without any thinking or conscious control. For example, when you touch a hot object, you quickly pull your hand away before you even realize what happened. Reflex actions help protect our body from harm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reflex actions are NOT slow and do not require thinking. They are very fast, automatic responses that happen without any conscious control. For example, when a bright light shines in your eyes, you blink automatically to protect your eyes. Reflex actions help keep us safe and happen instantly, without any thought process.

questions.question_text: Looking at the sun directly is safe for our eyes.
questions.explanation_correct: Looking directly at the sun can damage our eyes. The sun's bright light and UV rays can hurt the sensitive parts of our eyes like the cornea and retina, causing pain, irritation, and even vision loss. It is not safe to stare at the sun as it can be very harmful for our eyes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think it's safe to look at the sun, but that is not correct. The sun's light is extremely bright and powerful, and can easily damage the delicate parts of our eyes if we look at it directly. Looking at the sun can cause temporary or even permanent vision problems, so it's important to always avoid staring at the sun or other very bright light sources.

questions.question_text: The spinal cord is protected by the backbone.
questions.explanation_correct: The spinal cord is protected by the backbone, also called the vertebral column or spine. The spinal cord runs through a canal inside the backbone, which acts as a shield to protect it from damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The spinal cord is not floating freely inside the body. It is protected by the backbone, which is a strong structure made of many small bones called vertebrae. The vertebrae form a column that surrounds and shields the spinal cord, keeping it safe from injury.

questions.question_text: The skin can detect temperature, pressure, and pain.
questions.explanation_correct: The skin can detect temperature, pressure, and pain. This is because the skin has special receptors that can sense these different types of touch and stimuli. The skin is an important sense organ that helps us feel and respond to our environment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The skin is a sense organ that can detect different types of sensations, including temperature, pressure, and pain. This is because the skin has specialized receptors that can sense these stimuli and send messages to the brain. The skin is an important part of the body's nervous system and helps us interact with our surroundings.

questions.question_text: The pupil is the part of the eye where images are formed.
questions.explanation_correct: The pupil is not the part of the eye where images are formed. The part of the eye where images are formed is the retina, at the back of the eye. The pupil is the opening in the center of the iris that controls the amount of light entering the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The pupil is not where images are formed in the eye. The retina at the back of the eye is where images are formed. The pupil is the opening in the iris that controls the amount of light entering the eye. The lens helps focus the light onto the retina, where the image is formed.

questions.question_text: The brain controls our thinking, memory, and body movements.
questions.explanation_correct: The brain controls our thinking, memory, and body movements. This is because the brain is the control center of the nervous system and it coordinates all the activities of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The brain is the main control center of the nervous system. It controls our thinking, memory, and body movements. The brain receives messages from the sense organs and sends instructions to the body parts to respond accordingly.

questions.question_text: The _____ is called the control centre of the body.
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is the control centre of the body because it controls all our body functions, like thinking, memory, and movement. It is the main part of the nervous system that coordinates all the activities in our body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is the correct answer, not any other part of the body. The brain is the main control centre that manages all the activities in our body. It is the most important part of the nervous system and is responsible for our thinking, memory, and movement.

questions.question_text: The sense organ for sight is the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The sense organ for sight is the eye. The eye is the specialized organ that allows us to see and perceive the world around us. It has different parts like the cornea, pupil, lens, and retina that work together to help us see.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The sense organ for sight is not the nose, tongue, or skin - it is the eye. The eye is the correct answer because it is the specialized organ that allows us to see. The eye has different parts like the cornea, pupil, lens, and retina that work together to help us perceive visual information.

questions.question_text: We use our _____ to hear sounds.
questions.explanation_correct: We use our ears to hear sounds because the ears are the sense organs that are specially designed to detect and process sound waves. The outer ear, ear canal, and eardrum work together to capture sound vibrations and send them to the brain for interpretation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'ears'. We do not use our eyes, nose, tongue, or skin to hear sounds. The ears are the only sense organs that can detect and interpret sound waves. The different parts of the ear work together to allow us to hear the world around us.

questions.question_text: The _____ cord connects the brain to the rest of the body.
questions.explanation_correct: The spinal cord connects the brain to the rest of the body. It is the main pathway that carries messages between the brain and the body's nerves, allowing the brain to control and coordinate all body activities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'spinal'. The spinal cord is the correct answer because it is the part of the nervous system that connects the brain to the rest of the body. The brain is the control center, and the spinal cord acts as the main pathway to carry messages between the brain and the body's nerves, allowing the brain to control and coordinate all body activities.

questions.question_text: The sense of touch is associated with the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The sense of touch is associated with the skin because the skin has special receptors that can detect different types of touch, such as pressure, temperature, and pain. When you touch something, these receptors in the skin send messages to your brain, allowing you to feel and understand what you are touching.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'skin'. The sense of touch is not associated with the eyes, ears, nose, or tongue. These sense organs are responsible for the senses of sight, hearing, smell, and taste, respectively. The skin is the organ that contains the receptors that allow us to feel and sense touch, pressure, temperature, and pain.

questions.question_text: A quick automatic response to a stimulus is called a _____ action.
questions.explanation_correct: A reflex is a quick, automatic response to a stimulus that helps protect the body. When something touches your eye, you blink automatically to protect it - this is an example of a reflex action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The answer 'reflex' is correct. A reflex is a fast, automatic response that helps keep our body safe. For example, if you touch something hot, you automatically pull your hand away. This quick reaction is called a reflex action. It is different from a voluntary action that you control with your brain.

questions.question_text: The _____ controls the amount of light entering the eye.
questions.explanation_correct: The pupil is the opening in the center of the iris that controls the amount of light entering the eye. The pupil gets bigger in low light to let more light in, and smaller in bright light to prevent too much light from entering the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cornea is the clear front part of the eye, but it does not control the amount of light. The pupil is the correct answer, as it is the opening that gets bigger or smaller to adjust the amount of light entering the eye.

questions.question_text: Images are formed on the _____ of the eye.
questions.explanation_correct: The retina is the part of the eye that contains light-sensitive cells called photoreceptors. These photoreceptors convert the light that enters the eye into electrical signals, which are then sent to the brain to form an image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'retina'. The retina is the part of the eye where images are formed. Light enters the eye through the cornea and pupil, and is focused by the lens onto the retina at the back of the eye. The retina contains light-sensitive cells that convert the light into electrical signals, which are then sent to the brain to be processed into an image.

questions.question_text: The _____ vibrates when sound waves enter the ear.
questions.explanation_correct: The eardrum is the thin layer of skin at the end of the ear canal. When sound waves enter the ear, they make the eardrum vibrate, which then sends messages to the brain so we can hear the sound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'eardrum'. The eardrum is the part of the ear that vibrates when sound waves enter the ear. It is a thin layer of skin that is located at the end of the ear canal. This vibration then sends messages to the brain, allowing us to hear the sound.

questions.question_text: _____ carry messages to and from the brain.
questions.explanation_correct: The nervous system is made up of the brain, spinal cord, and nerves. The nerves are like pathways that carry messages to and from the brain, allowing the body to respond to the environment and control its functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Nerves'. Nerves are the part of the nervous system that carry messages and signals between the brain and the rest of the body. They act like wires, transmitting information in both directions so the brain can control the body's functions and the body can send information back to the brain.

questions.question_text: The transparent outer covering of the eye is called the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The transparent outer covering of the eye is called the cornea. It helps the eye focus light to form a clear image on the back of the eye, called the retina.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'cornea'. The cornea is the clear, curved front part of the eye that helps focus light. It is not the same as the pupil, which is the opening in the centre of the iris that lets light into the eye. The cornea is the right answer in the format requested - 'cornea'.

questions.question_text: The brain is protected by a bony structure called the _____.
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is protected by a bony structure called the skull. The skull is a hard, protective casing that surrounds and shields the brain from injury and damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is not protected by the spinal cord. The spinal cord is a long, thick bundle of nerves that extends from the base of the brain down the back. The brain is protected by a special bony structure called the skull, which is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Arrange the path of a message from stimulus to response:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: 'Sense organ detects stimulus', 'Nerves carry message to brain', 'Brain processes the message', 'Response is made'. This is the correct flow because the sense organ first senses something, then the nerves carry that information to the brain, the brain understands the message, and then the body responds to it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: 'Brain processes the message', 'Sense organ detects stimulus', 'Nerves carry message to brain', 'Response is made'. This is wrong because the brain can't process a message before the sense organ detects the stimulus. The message has to go from the sense organ to the brain first, then the brain can understand it and make a response.

questions.question_text: Arrange the parts of the eye from outside to inside:
questions.explanation_correct: The parts of the eye are arranged from outside to inside as Cornea, Lens, and Retina. This is because light first passes through the transparent Cornea, then the Lens focuses the light, and finally the light reaches the Retina at the back of the eye, where the image is formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The parts of the eye are not arranged as Retina, Cornea, Lens. The correct order from outside to inside is Cornea, Lens, and Retina. The Cornea is the transparent front part of the eye, the Lens is behind the Cornea and focuses the light, and the Retina is at the back of the eye where the image is formed.

questions.question_text: Arrange the path of light entering the eye:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Light enters through the cornea, passes through the pupil, gets focused by the lens, and finally forms an image on the retina. This is the path light takes to reach the retina, which is the light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be: Image formed on retina, Light enters through cornea, Light passes through pupil, Lens focuses light. This is wrong because light first enters the eye through the cornea, then passes through the pupil, gets focused by the lens, and only then forms an image on the retina at the back of the eye.

questions.question_text: Arrange the parts of the ear from outside to inside:
questions.explanation_correct: The parts of the ear are arranged from outside to inside as Outer ear, Ear canal, and Eardrum. This is the correct order because sound waves first enter through the Outer ear, then travel through the Ear canal, and finally reach the Eardrum inside the ear.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order of the parts of the ear from outside to inside is Outer ear, Ear canal, and Eardrum. If the order was arranged as Eardrum, Ear canal, Outer ear, it would be incorrect because sound waves first enter through the Outer ear, then travel through the Ear canal, and finally reach the Eardrum inside the ear.

questions.question_text: Arrange the parts of the nervous system by size (largest to smallest):
questions.explanation_correct: The brain is the largest part of the nervous system, followed by the spinal cord, and then individual nerves. This is because the brain is the main control center that coordinates all body functions, while the spinal cord connects the brain to the rest of the body, and the individual nerves branch out from the spinal cord to carry messages to and from different parts of the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The order from largest to smallest is not 'Individual nerve, Spinal cord, Brain'. The brain is the largest part of the nervous system, as it is the main control center that coordinates all body functions. The spinal cord is larger than individual nerves, as it connects the brain to the rest of the body and allows communication between them.
